profileText: A Representative from New York; born in New York City March 19, 1762; was educated under private tutors; was graduated from Columbia College (now Columbia University), New York City, in 1788; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in New York City in 1789; also engaged in banking; elected as a Republican to the Eighth Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Isaac Bloom; reelected to the Ninth and Tenth Congresses and served from October 17, 1803, to March 3, 1809; was not a candidate for renomination in 1808; resumed the practice of law; judge of the court of common pleas of Dutchess County 1828-1830; died at his home, ``Mount Gulian,'' near Fishkill, Dutchess County, N.Y., March 29, 1834; interment in Trinity Church Cemetery, Fishkill, N.Y.

note.content: Elected to fill vacancy caused by death of Isaac Bloom, and took his seat October 17, 1803.

researchRecord.name: In the Fish Family Papers, ca. 1780-1860, 14 linear feet.
1825-1835, 1 volume.
researchRecord.description: A receipt book dated 1825-1835, from Matteawan (now Beacon, N.Y.) and Fishkill, N.Y. They deal with household expenses: wages, taxes, newspaper subscriptions. There are also receipts on loose pieces of paper, some preprinted, laid into the volume. After Daniel Verplanck's death, some receipts name his estate, some his widow, Anne, and some one of his sons, James DeLancey Verplanck.

researchRecord.name: In the Gulian C. Verplanck Papers, ca. 1805-1857, 10 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Persons represented include Daniel C. Verplanck.

researchRecord.name: In the Verplanck Family Papers, 1689-1912, 0.7 cubic foot.
researchRecord.description: Persons represented include Daniel C. Verplanck.
